title: Africa Today
description: News and analysis from the BBC's Focus on Africa. The Africa Today podcast is published from Monday to Friday. It contains the day's top African stories.

episodes.title: A shorter term in office for Liberia's President?
episodes.subtitle: Liberians vote in a referendum aimed at shortening presidential term durations
episodes.description:
Liberians are voting in Senatorial elections and a referendum looking to shorten the duration of presidential terms - something which current president George Weah is backing. Confusing? We try to clarify

What do Nigerian religious authorities make of the United States decision to add their country to a list of "countries of concern" for violations of religious freedom?

And why a row is brewing between Kenya and Somalia over the production of the stimulant herb known as Khat

episodes.title: Ghanians have been voting in Presidential and Parliamentary elections
episodes.subtitle: More than 17 million people are eligible to vote.
episodes.description:
Ghana's Electoral Commission has pledged to deliver a free and fair election within 24 hours

There were calls to resume #EndSARS protests in Nigeria, but did they happen?

And, Oscar winning actor Forest Whitaker talks about the Peace and Development Initiative  he set up to help Africa youth.

episodes.title: TPLF condemns Abiy’s ‘path to destruction’
episodes.subtitle: TPLF’s message to the Ethiopian prime minister is that civilian lives are being lost
episodes.description:
A spokesperson for the TPLF says his message to the Ethiopian prime minster is that his “path to destruction” is resulting in the loss of civilian lives.

Plus the African human rights court has issued a landmark opinion on colonial era vagrancy laws that criminalise loitering, begging, or homelessness.

And the Resident Presidents mourn the passing of dear friends.

episodes.title: Liberia’s former rebel leader goes on trial for war crimes
episodes.subtitle: Alieu Kosiah is accused of murder, the recruitment of child soldiers, and rape
episodes.description:
Former Liberian rebel commander Alieu Kosiah has appeared in a Swiss court charged with war crimes during Liberia’s civil war.

Plus a report on the challenges presented by Ghana’s poor roads and makeshift transport links,and why they matter to the upcoming presidential election.  

And we meet an award winning Kenyan yoga instructor, using his craft to drive social change.

episodes.title: Uganda: Bobi Wine back on the campaign trail
episodes.subtitle: Uganda's Bobi Wine says he has asked the electoral body to protect opposition politicians
episodes.description:
Uganda's presidential candidate Robert Kyagulanyi, popularly known as Bobi Wine has said that he will resume campaigning, after he met with the electoral commission.

Plus, is Nigeria becoming the epicentre of cyber-crime and lucrative scams?

And a Gambian politician says the National Assembly may have failed the electorate by approving personal loans for legislators.

episodes.title: World Aids Day: HIV drugs not suited for children
episodes.subtitle: Unicef warns children are being left behind in the provision of HIV services
episodes.description:
Children with Aids struggle to get access to the drugs they need, warns Unicef.

More Kenyans seem to be switching to greener, cleaner energy, but at what cost to Kenya Power?

And the university lecturers' strike in Sierra Leone that’s right in the middle of the exam period.

episodes.title: Nigeria reels after farmers' massacre
episodes.subtitle: Dozens of farmers were killed in Borno State during the weekend
episodes.description:
It's a day of reckoning for the Nigerian government, after a weekend marred by one of the bloodiest attacks on civilians in Borno state, possibly carried out by armed rebels linked to Boko Haram

Ethiopia: Media blackout is still ongoing in the northern Ethiopian region of Tigray, so we speak to the international red cross who have been coordinating rescue and relief efforts in the capital Mekelle

We have an exclusive interview with South Africa's former opposition leader Mmusi Maimane, in which he tells why he ended up quitting the Democratic Alliance party and what direction the rainbow nation has to take to diffuse a resurgence in racial tensions

episodes.title: Ethiopia PM meets AU envoys but bars them from Tigray
episodes.subtitle: The African Union is seeking to mediate in the Tigray crisis
episodes.description:
The Ethiopian prime minister has met the African Union envoys seeking to mediate in the Tigrayan crisis but has barred them from talking to the Tigray leaders.

Plus, a new report highlights how the elderly are often neglected in times of disaster.

And Olushambles or Oluchampagne? The wily resident president considers ways of boosting electoral chances.

episodes.title: Ethiopia declares assault on Tigray capital
episodes.subtitle: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed urges Mekelle civilians to stay at home
episodes.description:
Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed states he is launching the "final phase" of the army's operation in the northern region of Tigray and urges civilians in the regional capital to stay at home.

Plus, remembering Sudan’s former Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi who has died after contracting the coronavirus infection.

And good news for East Africa’s coffee growing countries as their product is rated to be among the world’s best.

episodes.title: Ethiopian minister says deadline to Tigray fighters has expired
episodes.subtitle: An Ethiopian deadline for Tigray fighters to surrender has passed
episodes.description:
Ethiopia's Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed rejects foreign interference in the Tigray crisis, after issuing a deadline to Tigray fighters to surrender.

Plus, sixteen days of activism against gender-based violence.

And we hear from young Zimbabwean filmmakers hoping to revive their industry.

episodes.title: Western Sahara: Morocco ‘had to act‘ says official
episodes.subtitle: Morocco’s Russia ambassador says they had to reopen road to Mauritania
episodes.description:
Morocco’s Moscow-based ambassador says Morocco did not breach the 29-year ceasefire agreement between Morocco and the Polisario Front and blames increased tensions on the pro-independence Polisario fighters.

Plus Nigeria has a new taskforce in charge of acquiring, vetting and rolling out the Covid-19 vaccine – what challenges will it face?

And we meet the UK-based comedian who reveals how being visibly Muslim and wearing a hijab helps her play up to, and challenge stereotypes.

episodes.title: Nigeria slides back into recession
episodes.subtitle: Economy hit by "perfect storm" of COVID19 pandemic, oil prices and... EndSARS protests
episodes.description:
Africa's largest economy has slipped into recession for the second time in five years, registering record-breaking unemployment figures. But it's not all doom and gloom, as some analysts see the recent news of a working vaccine showing some light at the end of the tunnel.

Ethiopia Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has given TPLF forces deployed in the northern region of Tigray the country a seventy-two hours ultimatum to surrender, as government troops advance on the capital, Mekelle.

World football's governing body, FIFA, has banned the head of the game in Africa for five years. We find out why

episodes.title: Uganda: Bobi Wine charged with 'acts to spread Covid-19'
episodes.subtitle: The Ugandan presidential candidate has appeared in court and released on bail
episodes.description:
Ugandan presidential candidate Bobi Wine has been released on bail after being charged with spreading coronavirus.

Plus a report on the female candidates who could be about to make history in Ghana’s upcoming elections.

And the Resident Presidents rejoice that a Covid-19 vaccine could soon be available.

episodes.title: Uganda: Bobi Wine’s wife denied access to him
episodes.subtitle: The Ugandan presidential candidate is being held by police
episodes.description:
The wife of Ugandan opposition leader popularly known as Bobi Wine, says she has not been allowed to see her husband since he was arrested while on the campaign trail.

Plus there are growing security concerns in Burkina Faso, as the country gears up for elections.

And we hear from the son of the late Afrobeat legend Fela Kuti, on why he is reviving his father’s political party.

episodes.title: Uganda’s Bobi Wine is arrested on campaign trail
episodes.subtitle: The Ugandan presidential candidate was arrested during an election rally
episodes.description:
Ugandan presidential candidate and musician, Bobi Wine, whose real name is Robert Kyagulanyi, was arrested while campaigning in the east of the country.

Plus, the DRC declares that the Ebola outbreak is at an end.

And we hear from the eighteen-year-old Zimbabwean who's won the hearts and minds of the British public with her angelic singing.

episodes.title: Zambia defaults on its debt
episodes.subtitle: Zambia becomes the first African economy to default on its debt since COVID-19 started
episodes.description:
Zambia's economy becomes the first casualty of the COVID-19 pandemic following the country defaulting on its sovereign debt. Our financial analyst from Lusaka, Trevor Hambayi, tells us how this economic default will be likely to impact Zambians.

We bring you an update on the worsening conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray region where a three-day deadline the central government imposed on TPLF fighters has expired.

We also hear about the curious case of Shepherd Bushiri, a millionaire Malawian church pastor who skipped bail in South Africa to resurface a few days later in his home country.

episodes.title: Zambia defaults on its debt
episodes.subtitle: Zambia becomes the first African economy to default on its debt since COVID-19 started
episodes.description:
Zambia's economy becomes the first casualty of the COVID-19 pandemic following the country defaulting on its sovereign debt. Our financial analyst from Lusaka, Trevor Hambayi, tells us how this economic default will be likely to impact Zambians.

We bring you an update on the worsening conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray region where a three-day deadline the central government imposed on TPLF fighters has expired.

We also hear about the curious case of Shepherd Bushiri, a millionaire Malawian church pastor who skipped bail in South Africa to resurface a few days later in his home country.

episodes.title: Ethiopia: Fears Tigray fighting could spread
episodes.subtitle: The TPLF says it carried out a rocket attack on Eritrea as refugees flee to Sudan
episodes.description:
We get the latest on fighting in Tigray, with Ethiopian federal troops fighting TPLF forces. The conflict there is already causing concern beyond Ethiopia’s borders, with thousands of people fleeing into neighboring Sudan, and the TPLF saying it was behind a rocket attack on Eritrea’s capital.

Plus, the results of a year-long investigation in Kenya, lifting the lid on the sinister trade in stolen children.

And we hear from our health correspondent Rhoda Odiambo in Nairobi, who has news on yet another new COVID-19 vaccine

episodes.title: Ethiopia issues arrest warrants for Tigray leaders
episodes.subtitle: The Ethiopian government issues arrest warrants for top Tigray officials of the TPLF
episodes.description:
The Ethiopian government has issued arrest warrants for the top Tigray officials who run the state and other prominent members of the Tigrayan People’s Liberation Front (TPLF).

Plus we hear from the Kenyan senator challenging colonial-era norms by wearing traditional Maasai dress to the National Assembly.

And the Resident Presidents weigh up the benefits of starting a civil war.

episodes.title: Ghana ex-President JJ Rawlings dies aged 73
episodes.subtitle: Former President Rawlings died in hospital in the capital, Accra, after a short illness
episodes.description:
Ghana is observing seven days of mourning following the death of former president and military ruler, Jerry John Rawlings.

An investigation in Tanzania uncovers allegations of human rights abuses at a diamond mine.

And an art exhibition, that is not so much about the quality but rather its feel good spirit, opens in Cape Town.

episodes.title: Ethiopian refugees stream into Sudan
episodes.subtitle: Thousands of Ethiopians are expected to cross into Sudan, to escape the Tigray conflict
episodes.description:
As the Tigray crisis in Ethiopia escalates, aid agencies warn that up to 200,000 people could flee the conflict into Sudan.

Plus Tanzania’s opposition leader, Tundu Lissu on why he had to leave the country.

And Togo rapper Elom Vince, on music, his new album and why he is not afraid to speak out.

episodes.title: Ground breaking results for HIV prevention
episodes.subtitle: New injection given once every 8 weeks better at preventing HIV than one-a-day-pill
episodes.description:
The Wits Reproductive Health and HIV Institute in South Africa has revealed the results of clinical trials showing a better efficacy at preventing HIV infections of a new drug injected every eight weeks over a pill currently taken once a day. We speak with the Director of Research, Professor Sinead Delany Moretlwe

We ask the ruling Prosperity Party of Ethiopia why military operations in the Tigray region are still ongoing. After a week of fighting and reassurance from PM Abyi Ahmed that operations would "wrap up" quickly, there still doesn't seem to be an end in sight to the conflict.

And we take a preview of campaigning in Uganda, where elections are due in two months. Will Ugandans keep the incumbent President or choose to dance to the tune of the main opposition leader Bobi Wine?

episodes.title: When will a COVID-19 vaccine be available for Africa?
episodes.subtitle: Hope for a COVID-19 vaccine grows as pharma giant claims over 90% efficacy in trials
episodes.description:
Pharmaceutical company Pzifer says advanced trials for one of its vaccines shows over 90% efficacy in preventing COVID-19 infections

Ethiopia's federal government says the violent dispute in the Tigray region will end soon - but are both sides ready to agree on a way out of the conflict?

And Libya's warring factions have begun a series of face-to-face meetings in Tunis to find a common path out of a nearly decade of strife.

(Photo Credit: Reuters)

episodes.title: Kenyan officials accused of Covid-19 corruption
episodes.subtitle: Kenyan officials suspected of stealing money meant for medical supplies face prosecution.
episodes.description:
At least 15 top Kenyan government officials and businesspeople face prosecution in connection for alleged theft of tens of millions of dollars meant for Covid-19 supplies. 

Zambia’s credit rating has been downgraded over mounting debt crisis.

We also meet the man responsible for carrying on the tradition of the talking drum.

episodes.title: US sanction former Gambia first lady
episodes.subtitle: The United States has slapped sanctions on former Gambia first lady Zineb Jammeh.
episodes.description:
The United States has imposed sanctions on the country's former First Lady Zineb Jammeh accusing her of corruption during her husband Yahya Jammeh's rule. The US treasury suspects her of helping the former president transfer money illegally, and controlling his assets abroad. 

Talks have continued between Mali's military junta and opposition parties to try break a deadlock over a proposed transitional agreement. 

Zimbabwe's plan to return farms to foreign white farmers who lost their land some 20 years ago under the rule of Robert Mugabe.

episodes.title: Cameroon army launches operation in North-West Region
episodes.subtitle: Cameroon’s security forces have launched an operation to restore security in Bamenda.
episodes.description:
Cameroon army launch operation dubbed  "Bamenda Clean." It  aims to restore order to the capital of the Northwest Region which the army claims has been the target of attacks by what it calls "terrorists and criminals".

Zimbabwe bans  mining operations in the country's national parks following an outcry over proposed mining activities in Hwange National Park by two Chinese companies.

South Africa introduce laws to try and deal with high levels of gender based violence in the country.

episodes.title: Ugandan Minister charged of attempted murder
episodes.subtitle: Deputy Minister of Labour Mwesigwa Rukutana remanded in custody on murder charges.
episodes.description:
Uganda’s Deputy Labour Minister, Mwesigwa Rukutana was today charged of attempted murder following a shooting incident during NRM party primary elections at the weekend.

Protesters in South Africa force the closure of Clicks chain stores because of an advert deemed to be racist.
  
Zimbabwe journalist Hopewell Chin’ono narrates his arrest and prison ordeal.

episodes.title: Global leaders call for free coronavirus vaccine
episodes.subtitle: African leaders join call for a free coronavirus vaccine
episodes.description:
African presidents are among world leaders calling for a free Covid-19 vaccine that should be made available worldwide.
 
The European Union pledges 480 million Euros to help revive Sudan's struggling economy.
 
Our Resident Presidents tell us why health experts aren’t their cup of tea.

episodes.title: Burundi orders WHO officials to leave the country
episodes.subtitle: Burundi gives World Health Organisation staffers 24 hours  to leave the country.
episodes.description:
Burundi has ordered four key staff members of the World Health Organisation to leave the country.
 
Clashes in Sudan’s South Kordofan region leave at least 26 dead. 
 
Our listeners share their experiences of life under lockdown.

episodes.title: Lesotho records first coronavirus case
episodes.subtitle: Lesotho became the last country in Africa to record a coronavirus case
episodes.description:
Lesotho today became the last country on the African continent to record a coronavirus case.
 
Cameroon's Julie Owono talks about her appointment to the board overseeing Facebook content.
 
Malawian artist Hazel Mak on her new ‘Unorthodox’ album.

episodes.title: Zambia closes Tanzania border as COVID-19 cases surge
episodes.subtitle: Over 80 new coronavirus cases have been discovered in Nakonde
episodes.description:
Zambia has acted quickly to close the border with Tanzania after a surge in Covid-19 cases near the national boundary.
 
Sierra Leone grapples with a spate of violence in areas supportive of the main opposition party.
 
And we hear from France-based singer YSEE on Tony Allen’s final recording before his passing.

episodes.title: Malawi Supreme Court upholds Presidential poll nullification
episodes.subtitle: Malawi Supreme Court has upheld the nullification of last year's presidential elections
episodes.description:
Malawi’s Supreme Court has upheld the invalidation of last year's presidential election results and ruled that Peter Mutharika was not duly elected.

Political tensions are rising in Ethiopia over the postponement of elections which were scheduled for August this year.

And the miraculous tale of a migratory Mongolian Cuckoo called Onon which flew from Kenya to Asia in just seven days - a journey that normally takes seven days.

episodes.title: Madagascar conducts mass Covid-19 tests.
episodes.subtitle: Madagascar conducts mass coronavirus tests in its worst hit area.
episodes.description:
Madagascar is conducting mass coronavirus tests in its worst hit area and more on its Covid-Organics.

Why are schools being vandalised during coronavirus lockdown in South Africa?

And the we hear from,ML Kejera, the first Gambian to be shortlisted for the prestigious Commonwealth Short Story Prize.

episodes.title: African countries lift coronavirus restrictions
episodes.subtitle: Some African countries have started lifting coronavirus restrictions
episodes.description:
Some African countries among them Nigeria, South Africa and Rwanda have started relaxing coronavirus measures but some of their citizens see it as an ill-advised move.

Tanzania President John Magufuli criticised for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

Somalia remains one of the most dangerous places to be a journalist in the world.

episodes.title: South Africa government outlines plan for COVID19 recovery
episodes.subtitle: South Africa government outlines stimulus for recovery from the effects of coronavirus
episodes.description:
The South Africa government has outlined a stimulus package to aid the country's recovery from the effects of coronavirus

The South African-Ghanaian entrepreneur helping light up Sierra Leone

East Africa face the combined threat of coronavirus and a second wave of locust swarms thought be 20 times bigger that the one which began last year

episodes.title: Thousands arrested in Morocco for Covid19 violations
episodes.subtitle: Thousands of people have been arrested in Morocco for violating coronavirus measures
episodes.description:
Police in Morocco have arrested more than fifty thousand people for violating coronavirus emergency measures

African nurses and doctors on how they are dealing with coronavirus on the frontline of the fight in Europe and the US.

And Angelique Kidjo repurpose an old song to help spread the message on coronavirus

episodes.title: Cameroon government admits military involvement in civilian deaths
episodes.subtitle: The Cameroonian government has admitted involvement of its military in civilian deaths
episodes.description:
The Cameroonian government has admitted the involvement of its military in the death of civilians last February

How the coronavirus pandemic has given the planet a lifeline 

Kenya government hunts a group of people who escaped from a quarantine facility

episodes.title: How a dip in global oil demand is affecting African countries
episodes.subtitle: A dip in oil demand around the world is having big effect on Africa's countries
episodes.description:
A dip in oil demand around the world is having big effect on Africa's countries big producers Nigeria and Angola.

We hear from a hand washing expert who is on a mission to save lives and she also has tips on how to keep clean even when there's no water. 

And a group of Kenyans question why they are being forced to stay in quarantine despite testing positive for coronavirus.

episodes.title: Coronavirus in Africa: Your questions answered
episodes.subtitle: A special podcast where we put your coronavirus questions to the W.H.O.
episodes.description: A special podcast where we put your questions about the coronavirus pandemic to the World Health Organisation

episodes.title: Climate Change Strikes in Africa
episodes.subtitle: African children and activists protest the dangers of climate change around the world
episodes.description: A world wide push to raise the alarm over climate change. And African children are actively involved in the demonstrations

episodes.title: Detained Nigeria Shia leader to be freed to travel abroad for medical treatment
episodes.subtitle: Supporters of Ibrahim El-Zakzaky have staged weeks of protests to demand his release
episodes.description: We explore the trials and tribulations of domestic workers in Africa; Dozens die in Libya drone attack; And the human breast milk bank newly opened in Nairobi.

episodes.title: Ethiopia Airways crash latest.
episodes.subtitle: A day of mourning in Ethiopia following the Ethiopian Airlines crash.
episodes.description: A day of mourning in Ethiopia following the Ethiopian Airlines crash.

episodes.title: Jobs jobs jobs
episodes.subtitle: How can Africa create the millions of jobs needed for a growing population?
episodes.description: The World Bank estimates that Africa's working age population could grow by as much as 450 million by 2035. So how can African countries create the millions of jobs needed to accommodate these people? This special episode of the Africa Today podcast hears from experts and innovators from across the continent.

episodes.title: Voter Registration Day in Nigeria
episodes.subtitle: Voter registration in Nigeria; Merkel in Nigeria; equality for South African Muslim women
episodes.description: Thousands of frustrated Nigerians try to beat the voter registration deadline, but the electoral commission refuses any extension; first, Theresa May and now, the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel visits Nigeria... what's on her agenda?  Equality under the law for women married under Muslim rites in South Africa.

episodes.title: European Leaders Continue Charm Offensive in Africa
episodes.subtitle: European leaders set stalls in Africa; Nigerian security; Soweto; fishermen and condoms
episodes.description: Two of Europe's most powerful leaders continue setting out their stalls in separate African visits - Kenya and Ghana state their wants; Nigeria's defence minister on his country's security crisis; Soweto in South Africa after the latest anti-immigrant attacks; and the fishermen staying safe at sea with the help of condoms.

episodes.title: Europe's Leaders on a Charm Offensive in Africa
episodes.subtitle: Europe's leaders in Africa; Germany returns Namibian skulls; uproar over a TV ad in Kenya
episodes.description: Europe's two leaders on multi-country Africa tours as evermore big world players woo the continent... we ask about the opportunities and risks for Africa; Germany hands back skulls of Namibians massacred more than a century ago; and an uproar over a TV condom advert in Kenya - what's so offensive about socks?

episodes.title: Soldiers in Uganda Caught on Tape Assaulting a Journalist
episodes.subtitle: Ugandan soldiers assault journalist; a year of BBC Pidgin; Wenger gets award from Weah
episodes.description: From Uganda, soldiers assaulting a journalist are caught on camera:  A police spokesman says the behaviour of the security forces will be investigated; Na waa oh!  We celebrate a year of BBC Pidgin; also, why is Arsene Wenger getting the Humane Order of African Redemption from Liberia?

episodes.title: Zimbabwe Awaits Election Results
episodes.subtitle: Zimbabwe - Results expected; five banks merge in Ghana; Congolese opposition hopefuls
episodes.description: Zimbabwe - presidential election results expected tonight; in Ghana, five banks are merged into one; and two strong Congolese opposition presidential hopefuls warming up for the presidential election in December.

episodes.title: India to Open 18 New Embassies Accross Africa
episodes.subtitle: BRICS meeting in South Africa, Zimbabwe elections; Eritrea's changing political landscape
episodes.description: Is New Delhi playing catch-up with Beijing? Zimbabwean women standing in landmark elections; will Eritrea's political landscape change now that the war with Ethiopia is truly over?

episodes.title: Military Chiefs Escape Attack in Cameroon
episodes.subtitle: Cameroon's military brass escape attack; UN embargo on South Sudan; Bio, 100 days
episodes.description: Cameroon's defence minister and army chief escape an attack by Anglophone insurgents; after five years of civil war, the UN imposes an arms embargo on South Sudan, the same day women march for peace in Juba; and Sierra Leone:  100 days of President Bio - the pluses and minuses.

episodes.title: Kenyan Lawmakers' Taxpayer-Funded Visit to Russia
episodes.subtitle: Kenyan lawmakers in Russia; the long shadow of Ebola; the multicultural roots of the ZCC
episodes.description: Kenyans wondering why twenty lawmakers went to Russia during the World Cup on the taxpayers' dime; a new study shows just how long a shadow Ebola cast on those who survived it; the multicultural roots of the ZCC; The Gambia's healthcare crisis.

episodes.title: EU Leaders Agree Deal on Migration
episodes.subtitle: EU leaders' agreement on migration; Ghana's electoral boss sacked; Resident Presidents
episodes.description: After nine hours of talks, European Union leaders agree a deal of sorts on migration; Ghana's electoral commission boss, Charlotte Osei, sacked, the information minister tells us why; Gambia's Adama Barrow's major reshuffle; and the Resident Presidents on the merits or not of a lie detector.

episodes.title: Ghana Imposes Ban on Tilapia Fish Imports
episodes.subtitle: Why has Ghana banned tilapia imports? Ebola in the DRC; deadly fire in Nairob
episodes.description: Why has Ghana slapped a ban on all imports of tilapia?  The Ebola outbreak in the DRC could be over but the WHO remains cautious; families continuing to try and find missing relatives after a deadly fire in Nairobi; and LGBTQ Pride celebrations in Swaziland.

episodes.title: South Sudan's Leaders Meet
episodes.subtitle: South Sudan talks in Addis; Eritrea and Ethiopia's peace overtures; Tunisia law reforms
episodes.description: South Sudan's warring leaders hold talks in Addis Ababa; Eritrea and Ethiopia's peace overtures; law reforms in Tunisia; and the government of The Gambia responds to the killings of demonstrators in Faraba.

episodes.title: The WHO Lists Snake-bites as a Global Health Priority
episodes.subtitle: Snake-bites a WHO priority; Dutch company claims Teff ownership; Kassé Mady Diabaté
episodes.description: The World Health Organisation says snake-bites are a global health priority; why is a Dutch company claiming ownership of Teff - an Ethiopian staple? Remembering the Malian music maestro, Kassé Mady Diabaté, who died last night.

episodes.title: Dam Burst in Kenya Kills Tens
episodes.subtitle: Hundreds homeless in Nakuru where dam bursts; a shortage of HIV medication in Liberia
episodes.description: A burst dam in Kenya kills 47 people; a shortage of HIV medication in Liberia; Ethiopia orders closure of a mine after protests; the prospects for the Gambia's capital as the city votes for a new mayor.

episodes.title: Fire Rages in Nairobi Suburb
episodes.subtitle: Thousands left homeless after fire in Lang'ata suburb in Nairobi
episodes.description:
Thousands left homeless after fire in Lang'ata suburb in Nairobi.



Also in the programme:  The UK High Court to sit in Sierra Leone to hear allegations of human rights abuses by a mining company; and antibiotic-resistant germs, could onions be the answer?

episodes.title: African Migrants Told To Leave Israel
episodes.subtitle: Israeli government orders 34,000 African migrants to leave or face imprisonment.
episodes.description: Israel gives African migrants three months to leave the country voluntarily or face forcible repatriation or indefinite jail terms. The daily life of a female Zambian UN peacekeeper in the Central African Republic. The Grand Mufti of Egypt proscribes the crypto currency, bitcoin. And exciting new music coming out of Africa in 2018 with DJ Rita Ray.

episodes.title: Kenya Election Watch: Former Chief Justice Willy Mutunga
episodes.subtitle: Dickens Olewe wraps up our special podcast series with a rare interview
episodes.description: In the last of our special podcast series about Kenya's elections this year, Dickens Olewe covers the twists and turns of the process in a rare interview with former Chief Justice Willy Mutunga. He explained his view that a new political party is needed to take the place of the current political elite, and why he would like to chair a commission of inquiry into alleged police brutality.

episodes.title: Chibok Girls: Three years after
episodes.subtitle: Almost two hundred students are still being held by Boko Haram.
episodes.description: Britain's top diplomat to Nigeria on the three-year long search for the Chibok girls; More than ninety migrants feared drowned after their boat sank off the coast of Libya; Eighty thousand teenagers in danger of missing out on school in Burundi.

episodes.title: Wednesday, 17th August 2016
episodes.subtitle: South Sudan's new Vice President Taban Deng Gai addresses key issues in the country
episodes.description: The new South Sudanese Vice President addresses key issues in the country and what political alliances will emerge in South Africa after recent municipal elections?

episodes.title: Wednesday, 10th August 2016
episodes.subtitle: Ahead of tomorrow's elections Zambian civil society groups call for a free and fair vote
episodes.description: Ahead of tomorrow's elections Zambian civil society groups call for a free and fair vote. Burkina Faso bans donkey meat and skin exports following huge demand from China.

episodes.title: Wednesday, 3rd August 2016
episodes.subtitle: Running battles in Zimbabwe; local elections in South Africa; Malian music sensation.
episodes.description: Running battles in Zimbabwe's capital, Harare, between police and anti-government demonstrators.  Local elections in South Africa - a major test for the ruling ANC.  Malian music sensation, Modja... plus more.

episodes.title: Monday, 18th July 2016
episodes.subtitle: HIV infections still the leading killer of African children aged 10 to 19.
episodes.description: HIV infections are still the leading killer of African children. And old attitudes to the virus still prevail; the AU postpones elections for a new chairman, so what happens next? And Africa's first Spelling Bee competition.

episodes.title: Tuesday 14th June
episodes.subtitle: Health experts warn of very serious levels of under-nutrition linked to obesity.
episodes.description: Health experts warn of serious levels of under-nutrition linked to obesity. In South Africa, Reeva Steenkamp's father says her killer, Oscar Pistorius, must pay for his crime

episodes.title: Wednesday, 25th May 2016
episodes.subtitle: UN warns billions could starve as extreme weather changes poison food crops
episodes.description: UN warns billions could starve as extreme weather changes poison food crops. 1000s of Zimbabweans march  in support of Robert Mugabe to thwart party infighting.
